number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								Even though this game is still (very) early alpha it is great.If you are interested be aware that currently the training is very minimal and you're going to have to poke around and experiment to figure out what works and what doesn't. Also, as things are very early alpha it is certain things will change over time.That out of the way, the retro sci-fi mood is perfect. Things can be a little frustrating, as the game UI tends to make you work to get information out of it, but that is actually part of the challenge. Because of the clunky controls the game is something of a puzzle game.Let me explain what I mean: The tools you have at your disposal are likely to be a random mish-mash of what you happened to be able to grab. You also have no real idea about what challenges you'll be facing until you actually get into the ship. As such you need to be able to predict what steps you need to take in order to succeed and figure out some way to use the particular capabilities at your finger tips to meet your challenges.A lot of times this means taking actions preemptively since the last thing you want to do is scramble to type in commands when you are already under attack. It also means that intially you are going to have a fair number of deaths as you learn what type of threats there are and completely new ones surprise you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								Duskers is a game about inanimate object attachment, you will become attached to your drones, that is no question.A moment before i decided to write this i was piloting a drone named 003 or 'Tim' through an unexplored room, opening a door i saw an object that seemed to shift slightly as my little buddies scanners observed it, promptly i reversed 'Tim' back the way he came and shut the door, i felt secure in the fact that i hadavoided the danger and saved my little buddy.Then his video feed promtly malfunctioned.Almost instantly i felt my heart drop into my stomach and through the command interface ordered him back to a secured room, shutting the doors behind him.After several tense moments his feed came back online and i let out the breath i'd been holding.Like i said, inanimate object attachment.Also the whole Explore, Adapt, Survive thing is here too.I was exploring a ship when i came across a hostile entity, i was forced to adapt through the sudden loss of visuals, Tim survived because of this adaption.So i guess this game delivers on it's tagline.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								SummaryThis game is essentially chess... in outer space... and you cant see the opponent's pieces... and the chess board is an unknown variable.Long story short, you're some sort of researcher, setting out to try and figure out what happened in a catastrophe, and why. You're given several hypothesis, and your job is to board derelict ships left behind in the catastrophe with automated drones to find evidence to support or disprove each hypothesis. Only problem is, every ship is a massive unknown, and presents hazards, including organic enemies of different forms, hull breaches, spontaneous radiation leaks, and just plain dumb mistakes, all of which can get your cute little drones killed. To avoid such hazards, there is a progression system. Your drones are given a variety of upgrades to suit your play style, including stealth upgrades, support upgrades, and combat upgrades. Your ship can be upgraded as well, allowing you to perform drone tasks remotely. Of course, you must search derelicts to FIND these upgrades. It also requires skill with your environment. Every derelict has doors that must be powered from outlets, and then opened and closed. This gives the player the ability to lure enemies into empty or useless rooms while you get the loot. On top of all this, you, as a researcher, have been dumped here with minimal resources. You must scavenge for your fuel, and scrap metal. Worse still, much like in real life, your equipment falls prey to wear and tear, and you must keep it well maintained.Progress and upgrade your ship and equipment, survive for as long as possible in the depths of space, prove your cunning plans against foes and obstacles, use strategy on a universal scale, and piece together murder mystery style clues find out what the hell happened to everyone. That's a pretty good combination, one this game pulls of well.InterfaceThe UI is perhaps the most beautiful part about this game. It's all done in 1980's style retro computing. No mouse is used, everything is done with keys, and you control everything by typing in commands to a command bar like some sort of programmer. As for visual information, it's basically done in the style of top down false color ultrasound images. Use of this kind of technology is actually quite plausible on drones and robots, as it provides them 3d images, espescially in the darkened interiors of a derelict space ship. It has a unique combination of being high enough resolution to know what's what, and how to get the job done, while also being low enough detail to leave the interior of the derelicts up to the imagination. And rather than simply being the same overused retro pixelated visuals common to indie games, these visuals are the first like it I've ever seen, and they have a logical reason for why it might look like that in real life. If you like not only sci fi, but 1980s style retro sci fi, this is a must have.NegativesThere are very few that I have. Being an early alpha, obviously there'll be the occasional issue, and it probably has less content now than it will later. For example, I found a glitch where the map had old ships frozen on the screen while I was looking at new ones.The only REAL complaint I have about an actual decision the devs had on gameplay is an inability to revisit old ships and star systems. This has twice caused me problems in the 2 or 3 hours I've played the game.For example, I ran out of fuel to continue in one star system, so had no choice but to jump to another. The problem is that you're given new fuel everytime you jump. This leads to an exploitable game mechanic, where in a player could have infinite fuel by jumping constantly. So, I understand  why they dont let you jump back to an old star system. But this essentially left me with 5/8 ships in my last system unexplored. There's a pretty simple solution here, why not just ONLY give new fuel when you jump into a NEW star system?Another example would be when I accidentally left 2 drone upgrades (including my only tow) on a ship because I switched the wrong direction when swapping with a dead one... AAAAND of course I couldnt reboard right after to pick them up... Now THAT I see no reason for. Only thing I can think of is devs want the player to keep moving forward, probably to really feel the consequences of mistakes, but truth is, im not so sure it's possible to ONLY move forward in a strategy game. Both of these mistakes of mine could've easily been preventable or recoverable in real life had I simply gone back after the fact. But that's just not an option in this game. Anyway, I think this one particular restriction in the game is the ONE thing the devs should probably reconsider.RecommendationsI'd reccommend this game to anybody who likes strategy games, puzzle games, management games, murder mystery plots, progression systems, science fiction, or retro sci fi technology. Basically, if you like Xcom, you'll like this game. If you're looking for something that's fast paced and exciting, then this game probably isn't for you (though it has its scary moments). This is a game you can sit down, and RELAX, playing for hours, and using your head more than anything else, much like chess.Gameplay Suggestions to DevsI see potential for a few cool new features.1.) Co Op multiplayer.Each player has their own 1-2 drones (limit to 4 drones means limit to 4 players). Sometimes players can use their own ships at the same time, allowing for multiple ships. Players can work together to solve a puzzle. This game feels well suited towards encouraging teamwork, much like the co-op in portal 2.2.) Competetive multiplayerI could also envision competetive multiplayer. There could be a matchmaking system that pits 2-4 players against each other on a massive ship, with 4 drones tops each. Players can either take the run and gun approach, or use stealth to do things like throw enemies out the airlock.Door control could mainly be done through interface computers, which would make those of strategic importance. Whomever has control of the computer in an area gets control over certain doors.3.) Finally, I'd like to see logs and clues become more of a focus in the game. Mainly, I'd like to see it be the case that players aren't just GIVEN logs upon docking, but instead, are required to search the ship to track down logs. Or better yet, even physical clues. Things like dead bodies or mysterious devices that can be towed back to the mothership for analysis. You guys could go full on NCIS with the game, and leave it up to the player to track down clues to solve the mystery. I think doing this would also provide a greater motivation to play. The main motivation now is exploration and progression. Throw in the tantalizing clues of the story you're creating, and they simply won't be able to quit. It would turn the players into a criminal investigator, who have to use their own intuition to find and determine the meaning of clues.----------------------------------------------------How this game has only 34 reviews is beyond me. Even in mere early access, it's well worth those 20 bucks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Duskers is the next game from studio Misfits Attic and represents a huge departure from their lighthearted puzzle game a Virus Named Tom. This time around, a dark desolate future awaits you with your only allies are drones and a lone command console.(This review is taken from the Alpha of Duskers, which at this time is version .21.  Screenshots and impressions may not represent the current version of the game. You can buy Duskers on Early Access now and the developers are hoping for three to six months of updates and work before officially releasing it.)A Dirty Future:Duskers’ story takes place sometime in the far future, where you awaken as the sole survivor of a ship with only a few days of fuel left and no clue where you are or what happened to the rest of humanity. Your only option are derelict ships, stations and more with no signs of life for you to explore. Aiding you is a set of basic drones that come equipped with upgrade modules that let them perform specific tasks.Duskers' universe is entirely procedurally generated when you start a new game and you are given a random assortment of drones and upgrades. The universe is broken down into systems and then sectors that have places for you to explore. How it works is that in each sector, you have a limited number of proportion jets to move within the sector. When they run out, you need to enter warp via fuel cells in order to replenish them, fuel cells are found on ships and if you run out, you will be stranded.With a procedurally generated universe, a playthrough of Duskers can take vastly different turnsEach derelict is also procedurally generated and before you enter one, you'll be given an idea of what it is, how long it has been adrift and if there are any infestations or enemy types on board.All this is presented using a dirty tech aesthetic; where even though you're in the future, there are basic readout screens similar to the movie Alien. The game's commitment to this aesthetic is great and it really helps to set the mood; not only that, but you can play the entire game using a keyboard thanks to it.After selecting your target and equipping your drones, it's time to step foot into the unknown and where Duskers takes the dirty tech aesthetic even further.Command Prompt:The gameplay of Duskers is all about commanding your drones to explore and recover useful information and resources; however you're not going to be seeing the universe for what it is. Instead, the entire game is played through the viewpoint of your command console and all footage is fed to you via the drones' camera system. You can directly move a drone via the keyboard, but to do multiple orders and take charge, you need to use the command console.On the bottom right corner of the screen, you have a command prompt that lets you issue orders to the ship and the drones themselves. Opening and closing doors require you to type in the door code into the console and you can command multiple drones to move via "navigate" and the drone numbers. You can view the entire schematic of the ship via the spacebar; this allows you to see all room numbers and their respective door codes. Upgrades which are attached to your drones can be used by typing their name into the command prompt and there is a help guide for more information on what they do.Ship exploration hinges on your use of the command prompt and keeping an eye on the schematics to figure out what's going on The upgrades are very important as they are your sole means of interacting with the world. "Generator" and "Gather" are the two big ones at the start; the former allows you to turn on generators to power up sections of the ship and gather lets you pick up scrap and fuel.Things start out innocently enough, as you find upgrade modules that you can take back and even more drones to take into a ship, but then things change. You'll soon find that the universe is filled with hostiles of a variety of types, and they are out to destroy your drones and your only means of survival.Duskers shows a lot of promise as an up and coming rogue-like, even at this very early stage of Alpha. I'm curious to see if or how the game's mechanics will be expanded upon and what things will be added to give the game a greater plot.(For more reviews, videos, and podcasts on a variety of games, check out Game-Wisdom[Game-wisdom.com]

content:
Posted: March 13
												This game is good, but certain elements could use polish. Still worth a buy if you've got a few bucks to spare, but my problems are as follows:The camera limits your view downwards when opening doors, so if you're unfortunate and can't peek from the side, or up - you're inherently disadvantaged.Swarms being a brutal enemy is fine, but their hitboxes regarding opening and closing doors is clunky and rather broken. Often times I've found myself trying to close a door with them clearly outside the doorway, only to have it claim to be "blocked" and having me get wiped out. When your timing is spot on, it's sad to watch everything crumble. It's a risky, skill based play, but they seem to interfere with doors regularly.Slimes are also a fine enemy, but I find that late game they're all I run into - and it ruins the overall feel of the game. The lack of a true endgame is a downer to me, but it's not a big deal to others - so I'd say it's subjective.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 15
												The short of it: an innovative game with great puzzle-solving features, but with one major issue that brings it down a bit.The long of it: Duskers is a game right up my alley - a sci-fi horror environment where you're a lone human on a starship forced to loot derelict starships to survive in an universe that has seemingly gone dead... though not entirely, as the derelicts have "occupants" of sorts. The drones you use become your companions and your lifeline, and the game's rogue-like nature means that you never know what to expect, forcing you to problem-solve and change strategies on the fly. Honestly, I really enjoyed the core gameplay, even through the frustrating moments when luck conspires against you and your hard work comes crashing down. Even though the game uses a typing interface for most of the drones' commands, it's done pretty well and with plenty of helpful information. But there's a serious con, at least for me, and yes there's ***SPOILERS*** here.The game states that your objectives are to survive, uncover the mystery of humanity's downfall, and see if there are survivors out there. It actually LIES about the last two objectives. You have a bunch of text logs that get uncovered as you explore various ships in various ways, expousing theories on what happened. But I began to get suspicious about where things were going after "solving" one theory that went nowhere, so I went a-Interneting. Turns out, there's no true answers, no final confrontations, no hidden sanctuary. The game really is only a "survive until you can't" kind of game, and that is a MAJOR letdown to me. The best rogue-like games I've played, like FTL or The Binding of Issac, had end-games, conclusions. You felt like all your failures, all your frustrations, were heading to something. Here, there's just endless ruin. I intially played through the frustrations because I thought the game had something at the end to offer. If it had been advertised as just a survival game, if it hadn't pretended to be more than that, I might not be as disappointed. I stopped playing as soon as I found out the truth, and that definitely knocks that game down a few pegs. ***END SPOILERS***Verdict: I'm still recommending it despite my disappointment, because I did enjoy the hours I spent playing. The gameplay is novel and addicting, and pretty polished at this stage. But I will say that A) if you buy it, know that it's a game of endless survival and nothing else, and B) you might want to wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
												What can I say about this game. Well for starters, this is a game where the entire thing looks like its from an old DOS operating system. The style of this game is what drew me to it, because I love retro style games, and this is one of the first that looks like its from an early dos computer, where there is no advanced graphical content (well not much graphical content at least). Your job is to sit in front of a computer, controlling drones with dos command prompt style commands to move the drones, use upgrades, interface with computers, etc, to find salvage, more drones, and most of all, fuel. The game is simple, you lose your drones, you lose. enemies come in a small variety, about 4 or 5 types, and you have to use door commands, motion detectors, stealth, and so on to try and either lure enemies to kill them, get them out of the way, or trow them out of an airlock (warning, you can get sucked out too, as well as any salvage, broken/disabled drones). I can say that this game will appeal to anyone who loves old dos command prompt controlled games, as well as anyone who loves games like FTL, who want something a bit harder and more simplistic at the same time.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												I have never been more terrified of a single game than I have in Duskers. While not a "horror game" itself, there is nothing more scary than watching all your hard work, decisions, slow methodical advancement go to hell because of one error in judgement or even, heaven forbid, you can't enter the commands fast enough because you screwed up and now you're trying to fix your mistake fast enough as you fat-finger all the keys...Luckily, the game has Rogue elements so the information you collect throughout your many playthroughs (and there will be many - fat-finger goofs or not) will contribute to telling the overall arching story (which seems like it's asymetyrical in it's advancement, but I can't be sure (Which would be an impressive feat if it was)) and actual objectives in the game as well. This is one of those games that makes the player the actual player, rather than the player playing a character (try saying that 3 times fast). The game doesn't beat you over the head with this and actually pulls it off quite well.  Story time: After one particular screw up (which I managed to save the majority of my drones) I had to wait for the "flickering power sources" in the ship to randomly flick on in the room I was in so I could activate a teleporter. No problem, I'll just wait a while. An hour later I realized that the derilict itself was powering down and I experienced all kinds of interesting things along the way like random asteroids that may or may not collide with rooms in X minutes. Loss of video feed from drones and overview. Random doors breaking open as things crawl around on the ship I was in... It was a nightmare, and by far one of the best accidential experiences I think I ever had on a game.All in all, I would tow this game to my ship again.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												Have you ever wanted to feel like Ripley from the original Alien?  That atmospheric tenseness that consumes you, that feeling of uncertainity, that overpowering sense of dread?  You are a drone operator aboard a slavage ship.  Your drones are not outfitted for combat.  But you enter an abandoned ship knowing full well that there are threats inside.  You need the scrap, you have no choice.  You need the fuel to continue your crawl through an empty universe.  A threat could be in the next room, or the next or even that room you thought you cleared.  Your drones take damage, you carry on, your drone modules break, you make it work; you do the best that you can because you need to keep persevering.  Aside from the incredible atmosphere, Duskers is a thinking man's game.  You choose how to best collect scrap, fuel and explore the universe.  Every ship provides new challenges but also multiple methods of solving them.   There isn't a best method of playing this game.  One approach might work best for one enemy type and completely useless on another.  You have to keep adapting and weigh risk against reward.  This is the best $20 I've spent on a game in a VERY long time.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
NEW UPDATERead this paragraph before reading anything else. The rest of my review is from when I first bought the game at the 1.0 release. I am now reviewing it a week later, and some improvements/discoveries have occured. Firstly, they seem to have fixed the door glitches, second, there actually is a way to get the same easy start every time (under difficulty settings), and thirdly, you can make the enemy types reset when you restart, too. I still think there needs to be a more in depth tutorial, because you see different kinds of dangers in the normal gameplay which appear to be environmetnal but you can't be sure (green blobs, etc.) and the effects of depressurization and flooding with radiation, as well as countermeasures, need to be discussed in the tutorial.The First Few HoursWhen you first load up this game, you're bound to be excited about the concepts, being alone in the universe with a mysterious breakout happening... What's bound to happen? Well, you'll start your first ship salvage with zero infestations, a quick resource grab that gets you moving a bit on your feet. Then, you'll have to plot your moves more appropriately as every other ship is infested and your drones are vulnerable. As you explore each ship, you may uncover a log relating to what triggered the incident, which you can look back on later. It's a very unique situation, and the gameplay style is just as unique. For the first few hours, this game is pretty enjoyable.The BUTOnce you play past the first few hours, this game quickly becomes repetetive and painfully difficult to progress in. You'll probably be very likely to use the Reset option to start over. It doesn't restart a salvage though... It restarts the universe right after the event. You're back to square 1 with a different drone loadout. And that safety net of an infestation-free ship NEVER returrns. For every reset, your first ship is already infested, and a lot older. The levels are a lot harder, and it's really frustrating to try and progress because sooner or later, you'll be bound to make a single mistake that ends up costing you your entire drone fleet. And there's only 1 save file. Oh, and sometimes enemies can kill your drones through CLOSED doors.ConclusionWhile this game would make a great short-term arcade game, I feel ripped off having paid $20 for it. There's not really a chance at progressing very far if you ever reset (which I have) and the enemies are sometimes prone to glitching (at your expense). Short summary: if it's on sale for less than $5, it might be worth your money. As for what I paid, I wish I was still in my return window.

												Duskers is a game unlike anything i've played before. I am a huge fan of permadeath and procedurally generated levels and this is righ up my alley. The game is very tough, but every time I screw up (lose enough drones which makes me wish i was dead) I know that it was my fault, that if i would have been a bit more careful or a bit more clever, I would have succeeded. content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Even when you turn down all the difficulty options, its still very difficult and unforgiving, like FTL. But its also very unique. Don't let the comparisons to other roguelikes fool you, though. Its not simply "more of the same". Its very unique. I also love the visuals. From the images it looks 2D, and I admit the gameplay is just 2D but the visuals are actually 3D with an overhead view. As you move around the perspective changes slightly, and you can see its actually 3d models and enviornments. And here, noise and post-affects are used as part of the gameplay visuals. They aren't just cosmetic like in all other titles. As the game emulates you viewing your environment through a sort of radar system.As a programmer I'm not scared away by the command line. And in fact I enjoy it in this game. You can control the robots yourself. But having that option to line up commands for them, lets you do more than one thing at once. Which is a real boon in a game like this.I highly suggest the Duskers. But I have to admit, there is a good chance you won't get very far in each playthrough. So I stress buying it turn a sale. Half the retail price, won't have you cursing bricks when you keep dying. The retail price will.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												I'm seeing a lot of reviews that don't recommend this game, so I think for a good review of this game, it should start with a few caveats of WHO WOULD like this game (actual gameplay review is below the line of dashes, 4 hours on record at the moment):If you like Rogue-likes and the frustration, permanence, and perserverance attached, you could like this game.If you're the type that explores every single room, douses every fire, finds every secret room, and will circles dungeon crawler levels over and over again to give the best chance of survival, you could like this game.If you like micro-management of units and inventory equipment analysis and forethought, you could like this game.Lastly, if you have a niche enjoyment of using keyboard and command lines, you'll LOVE this game. (ex: navigate 1 r2;stealth;d14 would make your drone use stealth, go to room 2, and open door d14 simultaneously)----------------------------------------------------Gameplay:  7Graphics: 8Audio: 10Replayability: 10+Atmospherically terrifying, danger lurks everywhere and a single mistake can end your run entirelyUnlike any type of game I've ever played. Unique interface and gameplay, but familiar dungeon-crawling mechanismsHigh difficulty that demands precision and forethought. Something as simple as assuming there's just 1 enemy in a room or leaving a door open can end your game.The devs really understood what they wanted and designed this game with that in mind. You feel like you're alone in a hostile universe doing everything remotely to survive.-So far, I have very little to complain about.  The commands and controls are tedious, but your immersion in the game can completely forgives that.  This game could be considered a sci-fi post-apacolyptic simulator in that regard, but there are things that can get tiring, like retyping 'navigate' over and over and etc.Thus far, it seems that there is a very unfair fuel-to-scavenging ratio. At least for me, I have ended up perfectly completing 2-3 derelicts (like levels in a dungeon, exploring derelict ships) only to find out there wasn't enough fuel to scavenge and my run is now dead. I might be missing something, but I have scoured the menus and help/tips manual to no avail.  The only thing I could find was something about commandeering a ship, but I have yet to discover how. This could solve the problem though.So all in all, I would rate this game very highly.  I will certainly revisit this review after some more game time, but I am absolutely loving it.  Comparing this game to FTL is deserved but somewhat apples-to-oranges.  Duskers is more like clearing the aftermath of FTL, once that universe has died to some giant plague. I feel simultaneously alone, lost, and powerful controlling my drones and creating traps for enemies.I will come back to review this after more time, but so far, I am absolutely loving this game.

Early Access Review
								A diamond amongst the rough. A nice little survival strategy game that is actually good.You play as a drone operator wandering a universe filled with derelict ships. Your mission is to travel this universe and find out what happened to humanity.-Pro's-*Great Graphics*Nice little story*For an early access its pretty damn good, all the items fit together nicely.*Actually takes some effort to keep all your stuff.*Doesn't spoon feed you the way other games do. If you lose something you lose it for good.-Con's-*Game is pretty barebones, but still great!*The degradation of your modules is way too high and really does need to be lowered/balanced.*Not a huge amount of ways to customise your drones at this point of development.*No mouse input (Doesn't really need it but makes it a little awkward to use).*Clunky UI*Would also like to see more modules, levels, aliens and overall more customisation for both drones and ship.*Side note actually: Really not worth the $20.00 at this point in time, id wait for a sale. Maybe in the future it'll be worth that kinds of investment.Overall I rate this game a 7/10 as it stands, I actually enjoy playing this for large amounts of time and never really get bored. Would like to see more stuff added which im sure is on the way. Can't wait to see where the game goes in the future!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Duskers is the next game from studio Misfits Attic and represents a huge departure from their lighthearted puzzle game a Virus Named Tom. This time around, a dark desolate future awaits you with your only allies are drones and a lone command console.(This review is taken from the Alpha of Duskers, which at this time is version .21.  Screenshots and impressions may not represent the current version of the game. You can buy Duskers on Early Access now and the developers are hoping for three to six months of updates and work before officially releasing it.)A Dirty Future:Duskers’ story takes place sometime in the far future, where you awaken as the sole survivor of a ship with only a few days of fuel left and no clue where you are or what happened to the rest of humanity. Your only option are derelict ships, stations and more with no signs of life for you to explore. Aiding you is a set of basic drones that come equipped with upgrade modules that let them perform specific tasks.Duskers' universe is entirely procedurally generated when you start a new game and you are given a random assortment of drones and upgrades. The universe is broken down into systems and then sectors that have places for you to explore. How it works is that in each sector, you have a limited number of proportion jets to move within the sector. When they run out, you need to enter warp via fuel cells in order to replenish them, fuel cells are found on ships and if you run out, you will be stranded.With a procedurally generated universe, a playthrough of Duskers can take vastly different turnsEach derelict is also procedurally generated and before you enter one, you'll be given an idea of what it is, how long it has been adrift and if there are any infestations or enemy types on board.All this is presented using a dirty tech aesthetic; where even though you're in the future, there are basic readout screens similar to the movie Alien. The game's commitment to this aesthetic is great and it really helps to set the mood; not only that, but you can play the entire game using a keyboard thanks to it.After selecting your target and equipping your drones, it's time to step foot into the unknown and where Duskers takes the dirty tech aesthetic even further.Command Prompt:The gameplay of Duskers is all about commanding your drones to explore and recover useful information and resources; however you're not going to be seeing the universe for what it is. Instead, the entire game is played through the viewpoint of your command console and all footage is fed to you via the drones' camera system. You can directly move a drone via the keyboard, but to do multiple orders and take charge, you need to use the command console.On the bottom right corner of the screen, you have a command prompt that lets you issue orders to the ship and the drones themselves. Opening and closing doors require you to type in the door code into the console and you can command multiple drones to move via "navigate" and the drone numbers. You can view the entire schematic of the ship via the spacebar; this allows you to see all room numbers and their respective door codes. Upgrades which are attached to your drones can be used by typing their name into the command prompt and there is a help guide for more information on what they do.Ship exploration hinges on your use of the command prompt and keeping an eye on the schematics to figure out what's going on The upgrades are very important as they are your sole means of interacting with the world. "Generator" and "Gather" are the two big ones at the start; the former allows you to turn on generators to power up sections of the ship and gather lets you pick up scrap and fuel.Things start out innocently enough, as you find upgrade modules that you can take back and even more drones to take into a ship, but then things change. You'll soon find that the universe is filled with hostiles of a variety of types, and they are out to destroy your drones and your only means of survival.Duskers shows a lot of promise as an up and coming rogue-like, even at this very early stage of Alpha. I'm curious to see if or how the game's mechanics will be expanded upon and what things will be added to give the game a greater plot.(For more reviews, videos, and podcasts on a variety of games, check out Game-Wisdom[Game-wisdom.com]

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Duskers is a rogue-like, real-time strategy game based around a survival aspect where the player is expected to scavenge, build, upgrade, and maintain his or her team of drones whilst exploring the deep and recently emptied recesses of space. Dangers are plentiful, and often times lurking within your blindspots, waiting for you to make a mistake or become just a little too comfortable with your surroundings. Only by piecing together fragmented and corrupted logs from derelict ships can one find out what exactly happened and why you seem to be the sole survivor of an undefined disaster.Is the game fun? At its core, yes. It successfully assumes the role of a rogue-like by making each playthrough somewhat different than the last with randomized loot and map, but not all the ships are randomly generated. If you're a fan of rogue-likes and find the notion of a slowly developing story to be a good reward for your efforts, this game is exactly that, and development for it is still on-going which is promising.However, I strongly urge people who're unsure about the game to look up Youtube Let's Plays before purchasing it. It is extremely unforgiving, and sometimes even outright cruel with random, unjustified punishment - and for C$ 20, this is a big factor to keep in mind.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Sci-fi Survival in-Space game, for true lovers of space simulations and survival tense genre games.You play as lone survivor struggling each day to find resources to sustain your ship and drones. A very simple concept combined with this unique lonely dark survival space atmosphere, tense, and immersive while you travel along the deep space searching for derelicts, life and answers.The unique and special touch of Duskers is the way you live and play this theme. You control drones through abandoned ships and derelicts scavenging what you can to survive. And you control them through line-command OS, hacking systems, tasking commands and piloting them the way you want.The chalenge is great, your decisions need to be perfect and fast... or you will not survive. The dangers in space are huge! From Ships with thousands of years that can collapse in any second, sucking your drones through the space if the wrong airlock is opened. Or something run off your precious drones in the dark firing all moving sensors toward your shutle. Immersive, panic environment, that remember old Alien themes, with simple graphics, this unique game can give you a couple hours of entertainment.Because the unique style behind this genre, i recommend that you see some footage from the gameplay before you buy, Duskers, i hope this game can evolve to a bigger game and explore this thrilling environment exploring this concept with huge potential!Perhaps one day.. we can see a bigger universe to explore, more advanced sensors in the drones, more complex commands and tasks, and a good narrative behind the scenes.Enjoy

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
NEW UPDATERead this paragraph before reading anything else. The rest of my review is from when I first bought the game at the 1.0 release. I am now reviewing it a week later, and some improvements/discoveries have occured. Firstly, they seem to have fixed the door glitches, second, there actually is a way to get the same easy start every time (under difficulty settings), and thirdly, you can make the enemy types reset when you restart, too. I still think there needs to be a more in depth tutorial, because you see different kinds of dangers in the normal gameplay which appear to be environmetnal but you can't be sure (green blobs, etc.) and the effects of depressurization and flooding with radiation, as well as countermeasures, need to be discussed in the tutorial.The First Few HoursWhen you first load up this game, you're bound to be excited about the concepts, being alone in the universe with a mysterious breakout happening... What's bound to happen? Well, you'll start your first ship salvage with zero infestations, a quick resource grab that gets you moving a bit on your feet. Then, you'll have to plot your moves more appropriately as every other ship is infested and your drones are vulnerable. As you explore each ship, you may uncover a log relating to what triggered the incident, which you can look back on later. It's a very unique situation, and the gameplay style is just as unique. For the first few hours, this game is pretty enjoyable.The BUTOnce you play past the first few hours, this game quickly becomes repetetive and painfully difficult to progress in. You'll probably be very likely to use the Reset option to start over. It doesn't restart a salvage though... It restarts the universe right after the event. You're back to square 1 with a different drone loadout. And that safety net of an infestation-free ship NEVER returrns. For every reset, your first ship is already infested, and a lot older. The levels are a lot harder, and it's really frustrating to try and progress because sooner or later, you'll be bound to make a single mistake that ends up costing you your entire drone fleet. And there's only 1 save file. Oh, and sometimes enemies can kill your drones through CLOSED doors.ConclusionWhile this game would make a great short-term arcade game, I feel ripped off having paid $20 for it. There's not really a chance at progressing very far if you ever reset (which I have) and the enemies are sometimes prone to glitching (at your expense). Short summary: if it's on sale for less than $5, it might be worth your money. As for what I paid, I wish I was still in my return window.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												Great concept, love the look and "retro" UI. You are a salvage ship operator, looting derelict ships using drones and a keyboard-only, command-line interface to control them. You can give them orders to follow or pilot any one drone directly via a top-down view with limited visibility. All commands can be issued from either view during a salvage operation. The general idea is to see how long you can survive.There is plenty to do in this is game, but it is relentlessly unforgiving. Expect to get hammered by the RNG a [i[lot[/i] -- sometimes you just plain have bad luck. Making progress is slow and "grindy", even with difficulty options (nice touch!) tweaked toward "easy".  The cost of upgrades, repairs, and/or equipment is high. Often, when you do seem to be making decent progress, a random hazard (of which there are many types) just crushes you so far back into the weeds you might as well have been killed (yes, it's permadeath if you do).Each derelict can only be visted once. Since each derelict is procedurally generated, its difficulty can vary widely. The game does give you some information (size of the ship, number of different types of enemies, etc.) that helps in general to gauge its difficulty, but sometimes it's best to just grab what you can and run, as the game wisely advises you.It's also possible to get stuck while salvaging a ship, not dead but unable to do anything.  In such situations, you can quit and restart at the point before you stared exploring the current ship, but you cannot explore that same ship again.This game has a "puzzle" aspect to it as well. It requires a lot of thought and careful planning, and the ability to react quickly and decisively when things go pear-shaped. The game does let you pause to think, but you can't see anything useful while paused. I expect to be playing this quite a bit. There's a lot to do in the game and it's clearly going to take a while to discover all of it.

												[Revised 6/5/16]  Previously I reported this as not recommended but it was due to a bug which prevented saving the game. (Obviously bad news.) Game does allow for saving progress in between "boardings" which is all I wanted.Game is great. UI is very minimalist which is both evocative of the setting as well as easy to learn. Biggest difficulty I face is my own adrenaline and the impact it has on my abiltity to type the commands necessary to save my poor little drones!  Also, typos which open the wrong doors allowing swarms of evil baddies to kill off drones on the other side of the ship are bad. Losing key abilities because I failed to repair them before they finally failed completely: again, very bad.The "plot" in the background of figuring out why all this happened and where everyone went is a minor factor. Would be more interesting if the computers on the ships I visited could reveal more information through "Interface" ability, etc.  (Maybe they do later on in the game???)Definitely one of the most fun and immediately enjoyable games I've purchased lately. Two enthusiastic thumbs up.

												Well ... honestly well worth the money. Reminds me a lot of FTL while not copying FTL and really inventing something new. So ... what's like in FTL1) Rogue-like2) Constantly low on supplies and jumping from system to system, hoping you'll have enough fuel3) Use your mind to deal with enemies which are not trivial.4) Micromanaging your "crew"What's different?1) Dark atmosphere2) You command a group of drones mostly from a terminal interface (thank God for aliases!)3) Story is quite rich compared to FTL. Of course depends on how long you can survive ... but it's interesting getting bits and pieces of information that help you puzzle what the hell is going on.4) If in FTL you could say you were a taking a role of a "captain Kirk", in this game you're more of a hacker ... an engineer, armed with only your wits to survive the wastes of space... kind of like Scotty. Or Scotty with knowledge and skills of Edward Snowden :DIf you enjoyed FTL and want to see FTL from a bit different perspective, give it a shot. It's worth it!Also the game runs on Linux, which is really big plus for me.

content:
Posted: January 5
												I'm a fan of rougelikes. This is a roguelike, horror, sci-fi, quasi-hacking style game that involves controlling a couple of bots salvaging some derelict spaceships.Unlike other roguelikes however (except maybe Telegltich) this game requires quick reactions alongside well thought out strategies in order to survive. When a creature starts attacking a bot you have seconds to decide what to do, so if you didn't think it through already you better be able to type fast or your bot is dead.Get the scrap or run away - get the resources but risk dying in the process. So yea, if you like roguelikes and the interesting style of roguelike this game is, get it.

												Great strategy game, that has a great 1970/80's Sci-fi feel. The text based commands are easy to learn and add to the urgency if something happens when your typing furiously to save your drones. The schematic and drone view are both good, the drone view is very reminiscent of Alien and Aliens, due to the similarities ebtween the targeting system of the auto turrents and the  smart gun and adds to the asthetic. The story so far is a little obscure but that could be down to my small playing time however it does feel from reading the data records that you collect something is unfolding however ive yet to see to much of it.Overall its a great game for fans of strategy especially if your looking for something a bit different and its definitely worth taking a punt (go) at.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 3
												I was never a fan of the retro-fad that seems to be so trendy in the game industry today (and, frankly, sometimes it seems to be just thrown in as a facade to cover the lack of effort / resources), probably because I'm gaming since 1991 and I'm quite fed up with the style: It was not retro, it was what computers could muster. I'm pretty sure that if NVIDIA was around by then no one would have really liked to build everything like it was made out by 2D Legos. I'm not a fan of puzzle or strategic games either...but Duskers was able to make me love things I don't usually like! You're a pilot, stranded with just a little bit of fuel remaining in a galaxy of shipwrecks, your only chance for survival and for understanding what the hell happened is to board said wrecks and use your remote drones to explore them. You control your drones and the movement of your ship on the starmap with a simple keyboard only GUI and the simplicity of the graphics here is really immersive: it feels like you're in one of those sci-fi universes where for some reason technology evolved staying true to the 1980s aesthethics. It feels like the voice-activated computer that Deckard uses to analyze pictures in Blade Runner, or one of the terminals from Alien. The only video feed you have is a simple top down visual of your drones exploring the boarded shipwreck and the only audio you have is the crackling of the statics and the simple audio feeds that your drones make announcing their movements and actions. All the thrill of the game is in clever exploration: every shipwreck you board is unknown terrain, every room potentially filled with aggressive...things you will never be able to name. You know you need that damned fuel and all the scraps you can gather to keep your ship and your drones up and running, but you have to keep your drones safe. The nicest thing about it is that you can be as creative as you like: maybe one of your drones can set mines and you can use it to neutralize menaces by luring them in "armed" rooms or maybe one of the drones can access terminals and command the defenses of the boarded ship. Inside the lonely hulls out there you can also find some downed drones to add to your small remote army and acquire new abilities to face the next jump in the galaxy. Towards survival. Towards the unknown. You are alone, in the whole vastness of the cosmos and the drones are your only friends, they are your eyes and hands and what separate you from a lonely, awful death...P.S.: Once I screwed during exploration and I blissfully hit the "Reset" option thinking that it would have restarted the scenario...boy I was wrong! It resets the WHOLE GAME! Be advised!

content:
Posted: January 4
												This game is tough, I mean seriously tough. One mistake and it's all over, it makes FTL look like child's play.The start of the game can be a bit RNGish, you need a bit of luck just to get a toe-hold in the game but if you can survive the first few ships you should have the ingredients to continue a long way - or until you make that next small mistake.The look and feel of the game is great, hugely tense and claustrophobic. Much is made of the command line interface but you soon get used to this and it just feels the "right way" to be playing a game like this.I'm very much enjoying this game.
